content:
This is a nice clash, but it really needs more tests to make it fair for Reverse mode.

There's only one test with commas in it, so it's not exactly clear whether they should always be removed or not.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is an awesome puzzle for regex lovers. Especially those that know lookbehinds.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: nice little puzzle with a nice shortcut with regex

I love it
It really test the users ability to find a space in a string
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Nice puzzle!
I would even recommend this as a shortest, if you cut it up to sentences with regex it is shorter:

import re

s = ' '.join([re.sub(' ', '_', sentence.replace(',', '')) for sentence in re.findall(r'[A-Z][^.!?]*[.!?]', input())])
print(s)
Nice puzzle for Fastest and Reverse especially for new Clash users. Shortest is just the most useless Clash that people should be allowed to filter out though :D

Goal section
* Please format ., ? and ! as {{constants}}.

* Please change "Each words have exactly one spaces" as follows:
   • "Each words" => "Words"
   • "spaces" => "space"

* Please delete "leading".

* Please add "There may be sentences with one word only."

Input section
* Please delete "One sentence can contain only one word as well." (as you can see, that would be moved to Goal section as part of the explanation as mentioned above.)

Output section
* Please change "leading spaces" to "spaces between sentences".

Thanks.
I am curious for shorter solutions as well, this is just a quickwin with simple logic usage.
Thank you for the quick feeback, please let me know if you find any more parts to change or rephrase.

You can shorten the regex simply by checking for a letter followed by a comma and space or just a space.

Regex: /(\w),? /
Substitution: '\1_'

Full ruby code:
$><<gets.gsub(/(\w),? /,'\1_')

I don't know Javascript, but in Python the shortest way I can find is also simply with a couple of .replace()-es. I tried list comprehension and one long ternary expression (print(''.join(c if c not in',.?! 'else c+' 'if c in'.?!'else'_'if c!=','else''for c in input())[:-1].replace(' _',' ')) -- 119 characters), but that is longer than simply using .replace(...) (91 characters, including the suggestion of Actual_bullet).

The nice thing about your clash is that there are some different mechanisms (replace spaces, but not all, remove commas all together), that prohibit the use of one method for all. Hence, you need a couple of replaces (or a couple of conditions), instead of one short solution.
--At least, that is my experience with your clash - but maybe someone better than me finds some smart short one-step solution.

Just cut it up to sentences with regex:

import re

s = ' '.join([re.sub(' ', '_', sentence.replace(',', '')) for sentence in re.findall(r'[A-Z][^.!?]*[.!?]', input())])
print(s)
Ah, regex - I need to study that a bit more indeed. For shortest, any 'import' is costly, but on quick check I can get your code to 112, while without regex I reached 119, so it is worth it here.
